CONFLICT, RECENT PROGRESS,AND THE CHALLENGESOFTRANSITION
1. The Democratic Republic ofthe Congo (DRC) is gradually emerging from a decade ofpolitical instability and conflict. War and civil disturbance, compoundedby the sequels of a longperiod o fmismanagement and corruption, have taken a heavytoll on DRC and its 53 million people. The conflict, inwhich seven foreign countries have been involved at some point, has been the world's most murderous indecades, with an estimated 3 million lives lost between 1997 and 2001.
2. Against this background, significant progress towards peace andreconciliation has beenmade since 2001, withinthe context o fthe Lusaka Agreement signed in 1999 by all key parties to the conflict and the consecutive agreements (see Box 1). The mediation o f the UnitedNations, andthe support o f key bilateral partners, such as South Africa, were critical inthis process. Despite ups and downs inthe stabilization process (which are a characteristic o f post-conflict stabilization processes), and some delays on specific issues, the situation has been steadily improving - although the challenges ahead remain daunting.

- 6 -  3. O n the military side, major fighting ended in2001. A UNpeace-keeping force, theMission d'Observationdes Nations Uniesau Congo (MONUC) was deployed throughout the country in2002. Foreigntroops present inDRC (in support o f rebel groups) were withdrawn in2002, following agreements betweenDRC and Rwanda(in July 2002) andbetween DRC and Uganda (in September 2002). With the support o f MONUC, Belgium, and South Africa, steps were taken inlate 2003 to merge regular armed forces and former rebel groups into national, integrated, and restructured armed forces - including the unification o f the General Staffs, the appointment and installation o f provincial military commanders inall provinces, and training activities. Similar efforts have beenmade to reform and integrate police forces since 2004. Inparallel, a National Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (DDR) Programwas prepared inmid-2004to deal withformer combatants -and its implementationis underway.
4. Inparallel, political negotiations culminated inanagreement on apower-sharing arrangement for a transition period leading to elections within24 to 36 months. Within this context, anall-inclusive Government ofnationalunitywithrepresentation ofall key armed groups, unarmedopposition, and civil society was appointed on June 30,2003. Steps have also been taken to organize elections (a referendum on the post-transitional constitution, legislative elections andpresidential elections), which raises not only political issues, but also formidable logistics challenges. Since its inception, and while muchremains to be done to healthe scars left by years o f conflict, the Government has demonstrated a stronger sense o f cohesion than could have been expected - and a remarkable degree o f cohesion as regardsto the design and implementation o f economic reforms.
5, Despite these achievements, however, the situation remains fragile. While progress inDRC compares well with stabilization efforts inother post-conflict countries, the challenges remain daunting. The size o fthe country andthe lack o f infrastructure combine to make access to certain areas extremely difficult -which translates into extreme poverty andpersistent insecurity inthese areas. Inaddition, the poor command and control structure o f the armed forces andthe irregular payment o ftheir salaries contribute to indiscipline withinthe ranks, which depend on the local population for their sustenance. And while provincial governors andvice-governors were appointed inthe 11 provinces and took up their duties inMay 2004, State administration remains weak.
6. The fragility o f the situation has been highlightedboth by the endemic violence which persists insome areas (notably inthe Northeastern district o f Ituriand in some rural parts o f the Easternprovinces o f the Kivus), and by the series o f crises which unfolded throughout 2004 (including localized explosions o f violence inthe Eastern part o f the country and urbanriots). O nthe positive side, however, the Congolese Government has been able to successfully manage these crises and to gradually appease tensions, with a relatively minimal involvement by the international community (limited to diplomatic mediation). Still, the appalling living conditions which many Congolese endure create an environment, especially inurban centers, inwhich minor sparks can easily and rapidly transform into full-blown explosions.
- 7 -  ECONOMIC STABILIZATION AND REFORM, AND THE CHALLENGES OF RECOVERY
The impactof the conflict
7. The years o f conflict, compoundingthe legacy o f decades o f mismanagement and poor governance, have taken a heavy toll on DRC. Despite its immense natural riches, the country is among the poorest inthe world. Infrastructurehas suffered considerable damage, inparticular due to the interruption o f maintenance (most o fthe road network i s no longer passable; entire provinces do not have accessto energy or clean water) -and entire districts have beenforced into autarky by the collapse o fthe transport system. Key institutions are inshambles. Many people have lost their assets-whether buildings, livestock, or tools. Investmenthas come to a halt and i s only slowly recovering. Public debt has dramatically increased, while public finance management has deteriorated. The vast majority o fthe population survive on informal economic activities, mainly carried out by women.
8. Overall, per capita income, at about US$107 (29 cents per day) i s only a fraction o f what it was at the time o f GDpp@b independence, more than forty years ago (see Graph 1). Prior to 1990, the Congolese economy was centered around 380 a broadrange o f competitive, foreign-dominated export activities, developed around the country's extraordinary natural resources (mining, agriculture, forestry, energy). This hadresulted ina relatively highlevel o furbanization- and it co-existed with traditional agriculture andinformal 1960 1997 m activities which provided incomes to a large part o fthe population. With the conflict, the formal private sector almost collapsed, with many enterprises losing assets, staff, and commercial networks. Traditional export activities almost came to a halt (to only 5 percent o f GDP) and services declined (from about 45 percent o f GDP inthe 1980s to 28 percent in2001), while the share o f agriculture substantially increased (from 30 percent o f GDP inthe 1980s to 54 percent in2001). Only 5 percent o f the active population has ajob inthe formal sector. Today's economy i s based on subsistence, or even survival activities: informal activities (small-scale trade, services, and daily labor) inurban areas, subsistence agriculture inrural areas.
The Government'seconomicprogram
9. Since April 2001,the Government has implementeda solid and ambitious program o f economic reforms, supported by the Bretton Woods Institutions. This program aims bothto spur economic growth andto tackle some o f the deep-rooted structural issues which have hampered DRC's economic development inthe past. Ithas been supported by the IMF through a Staff Monitored Program (SMP), between June 2001 andApril 2002, and access to the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) for the period July 2002 to July 2005 -and by the Bankthrough an Emergency Early Recovery Project (financed through an IDA grant andapproved inJuly 2001), an Economic Recovery Credit (approved inJune 2002), a Post-Reunification Economic
- 8 -  Recovery Credit (approved inFebruary 2004) as well as investment projects and substantial analytical work and policy advice. Overall, implementation has been consistently satisfactory throughout the period.
10. The results of this program are significant, even though they need to be further consolidated. Hyper-inflation was broken by the end o f 2001, and inflation has decelerated even more quickly than envisaged (at about 4.4 percent for 2003, about half the program target). Exchangerate stability hasbeenbroadly maintained since the Government floated the Congolese franc inApril 2001. Fiscal revenues are expected to reach 9.2 percent o f GDP in2004 (above the 9 percent target o f the program) -a significant increase from the 5.9 percent o f 2001 - and are expected to further increase in the years to come, to reachabout 12percent ofGDP (close to US$1billion) in2008. In the first quarter of 2005, however, the exchange rate deteriorated and inflation picked up. The Government has defined togetherwith the IMFa number o f corrective measures, and i s implementingthem in a satisfactory manner.
11. Inparallel, the Government hasmade significant efforts to dealwithan overwhelmingdebt burden. DRC reachedthe HIPC Decision Point inJune 2003 -with a total assistance estimated at US$6.3 billioninNet Present Value (NPV) terms, for a total stock o f external debt outstanding estimated at US$7.9 billion inNPV terms at end-2002 (US$10.7 billion innominal terms). The Completion Point is expected to be reached in late 2006, with floating triggers related to: (i)completion o f a full Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) and its implementation for one year; (ii) continued performance in terms o f macro-economic stability; (iii) effective use o f budgetary savings for poverty- related programs; (iv) improvements inpublic expenditure management; (v) enhanced service delivery and governance inpriority sectors (health, education, rural development, and infrastructure); (vi) adoption of satisfactory sectoral strategies and related implementationplans for health, education, and rural development; and (vii) improvements inpublic debt management. Steps have recently been taken, with support from the Bank through the Post-Reunification Economic Recovery Credit, to settle a domestic debt estimated at US$500 to US$600 million (including the audit o f most claims, and the selection o f a negotiator).
12. On the structural side, a solid program o freforms has been implemented, with significant achievements ina broad range o f areas (see Box 2). Reforms have been aimed at correcting major deficiencies -to spur growth through private sector activity, and to start tackling key transparency and efficiency issues inthe management o f natural andpublic resources. This has elicited a strong private sector response: about US$2.4 billion innew investments under consideration have been registeredby the Government since early 2003 (private capital flows to sub-Saharan Africa in2002 totaled about US$12 billion) ina broad range o f sectors (e.g., services, agro-business, constructions, natural resource exploitation). Flagship operations include a US$94 million cellular phone project by a Britishcompany, Vodaphone, a phased US$600 millioninvestment project by Congo Korea Telecom to install a telecom backbone inthe country, or the launch o f a three-year program to increase offshore oil production by a Chevron-Texaco- led consortium.

0 On the growth side, the economic collapse has been such that, assuming an average economic growth o f 5.3 percent a year, it would take until2060 to return to the level o f GDP per capita in 1960 - andwith an average economic growth of 4 percent only (and a 2.7 percent population growth), it would take about 200 years. The Government's capacity to engage inpro-poor spending, to improve living conditions, and to stabilize the social situation remains severely constrained by the lack o f resources.
-11 -  THESOCIAL CRISISAND THE RISKSITCARRIES
15. Progress towards political transition and economic recovery are taking place within a context of a severe social crisis. While political progress, economic reforms, and the return o f growth have producedvisible results inKinshasa and other places (for example inKisangani, where the re-opening o fthe River Congo inthe summer o f 2003 has resulted inhalving key commodity prices), poverty remains widespread and acute throughout the country - and hunger i s present throughout the country, with an estimated 16 million people having critical food needs, and the vast majority o fthe population consuming less than two thirds o f the daily calories neededto maintain good health.
16. While detailed data are still missing, all key social indicators shave sufferedmajor setbacks over the last period, and the chances for DRC to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) by 2015 are seriously compromised.
17. The social crisis carries very significant risksfor the success ofboththe political transition and the economic reform processes. Muchhas been achieved over the last period to move towards peace and reconciliation. But these achievements, while important steps forward, are only the beginningo f a process. The challenge now i s to consolidate past efforts and sustain the pace - so as to ensure the investment already made can yield the expected results. Inthis context, there i s a broad consensus that managing the social crisis and laying the ground for economic growth andpoverty alleviation are critical to the success o fthe overall effort -and require urgent action.
18. The risks are particularly highinurbanareas, where about a third o f the population lives (see Box 4). With a relatively large number o f urbancenters, and an urbanization accelerated by the conflict, cities inDRC are critical to both social stability and economic growth. Still, infrastructure and services have considerably deteriorated over the last decade. This has hadtwo consequences: urbanpeople are living in increasedpoverty with deteriorated social indicators, and cities can no longer play their economic role o f places o f exchange and pools o f financial and human resources (which inturnhasa significant impact onthe economic and social situationinrural areas). In urbancenters, economic collapse, deterioratingliving conditions and inflows of displaced persons hence combine to create a highlyvolatile environment, inwhich minor sparks can trigger major social explosions - as illustratedby the series o f riots and violence in June 2004.

THEDONORS' RESPONSE: A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE GOVERNMENT
The establishmentof a partnership
20. The Bank's responseto the challenges of transition and recovery inDRC is designedandimplementedas part of a broader donor response. The magnitude and complexity of the needs are such that the involvement of a significant number of donors i s required - andthat a strong coordination i s needed, not only among donors, but also betweenthe political, economic, and social processes. The Bank has played a key role in the mobilizationandcoordinationprocess, inparticular by organizing a series ofdonor meetings-donor information meetings to exchangewith the Government on the challengesandpriorities (inJuly 2001, December 2001,May 2002), Consultative Group meetings to mobilize resources(inDecember 2002, December 2003, and November 2004), and a stocktaking meeting (inJune 2004). A follow-up and stocktaking meeting is plannedfor mid-2005 and a newconsultative group meeting for end 2005.
21, As the Government was satisfactorily implementing its ambitious program of economic reforms, donors gradually stepped up their support, and inparticular provided significant external assistance. Such assistance consists not only inpledges, but also and most importantly inactual disbursements-which illustrates the fact that DRC's absorptivecapacity is muchlarger thanwas initially feared. Since 2001,disbursements have rapidly increased-from US$210million to about US$l,100million between2000 and 2004 (see Graph 3) -with over 25 donors currently engaged, including both bilaterals and multilaterals.

- 14-  22. Inparallel, the relationship between DRC anddonors went through a gradual transformation, to take the shape o f a genuinepartnership. This partnershipi s inspiredby the principles of the New Partnership for Africa's Development(NEPAD) -with both sides o f the partnership sharing the same overall objectives and a common approach and strategy - and with the Government focusing onthe design and implementation o f sound economic reforms, and external partners providing the type o f support needed, including financial assistance, needed for the success o fthese efforts. The MinimumPartnershipProgramfor RecoveryandTransition
23. To formalize the partnership, and following the recommendations made by the participants inthe December 2003 meetingo f the Consultative Group, the Government prepared a "Minimum Partnership Program for Recovery and Transition" (French acronym: PMPTR). The preparationprocess included intense consultations not only with technical institutions and entities -but also through a dialogue at the provincial level with regional authorities, private sector, andcivil society. This work was carried out with the support o f several multilateral organizations, including the World Bank, the United Nations Development Program (UNDP), and MONUC. It was presented ina draft form to the donors inJune 2004 -and formally endorsed during the November 2004 Consultative Group meeting.
24. The PMPTR i s a comprehensive transition and recovery strategy that clearly spells out the crucial principles o fpartnership, mutual commitment and responsibilities, Government accountability and the importance o f coordinating efforts at all levels - between the Government and donors, withinthe Government at the inter-ministerial level, betweenthe Government and stakeholders, and between donors. Itproposes an overall strategic framework for transition and recovery, and presents an articulation o fthe needs - for bothreforms and investments - ineach o f 16 areas, ranging from macro- economic stability to infrastructure, from the social sectors to the organization o f elections, from security sector reform to environment or rural development. The total cost o fthe PMPTR amounts to US$6.87 billion over a three- to four-year period (see Table 1) -which corresponds to about US$21 per capita andper year, significantly less than similar programs inother post-conflict countries.
25. The PMPTR is part o fthe overall PRSP process. It is a response to calls for an early framework as the PRSPis being finalized -so as to ensure an adequate focus for the efforts ofthe Government andthe support by donors duringthe critical coming years. Itis, however, part o fthe same single strategic effort aimed at defining avision for DRC's poverty reduction process. It i s based on the work carried out under the interim PRSP and duringthe early stages o fthe PRSP consultations. It is expected to inform the fullPRSP (which is expected to be completedinthe secondhalfo f2005), bothat the strategic and sectoral level.

The overall priorities ahead
27. Within the overall strategic framework ofthe PMPTR, key priorities for the period ahead were identified and discussed at the November 2004 Consultative Group meeting. Boththe Government and donors emphasized the acuity o f the ongoing social crisis and the needto rapidly deliver peace dividends, especially inurban centers, to keep the transition andrecovery process on track -with a strong consensus emergingaround the needfor urgentaction. Participantsinthe meeting also committedto a continued, strong partnership and agreed on the priorities for both sides.
28. Onthe Government side, these priorities are three-fold. First, move the political process forward -by re-establishingthe authority o f the State and security throughout the country, by implementingan in-depth reform o f the security sector, and by holding free and fair elections with a timingconsistent with the agreements reached withinthe inter-
- 16-  Congolese dialogue framework. Second, pursueeconomic reforms -macro-economic reforms, business climate reforms, and governance reforms (includingtransparency and the payment o f civil service salaries). And third, work towards social inclusion (in particular by removing legal obstacles to a full participationo f women and marginalized groups inthe transition andrecovery process). These overall priorities translate into a series o f key reforms at the sectoral level, as spelled out inthe PMPTR.
29. On the donors side, more and better assistance i s needed. With regardto the volume o f aid, donors pledged a total o f about US$5.7 billion for the next four years (the duration of the PMPTR) - and announced intended disbursementswhich amount to about US$1.2 billion in2005 (including a broader and increased support to the budget, as well as substantial assistance for the organization o f elections). With regard to the quality o f aid, donors agreed not only on the needto ensure a close coordination o f their activities, but also on the urgency to move the harmonizationagenda forward. With strong support bythe Government, a number o f donors called for the development o fjoint implementationmechanisms, including the pooling o f resources andthe use ofjoint monitoring and evaluation systems.
THEBANK'SOVERALLRESPONSE
The Bank's strategy inDRC
30. The Bank re-engaged inDRC through a Transitional Support Strategy (TSS), which was discussed inJuly 2001. A second TSS was discussed inFebruary 2004, which proposes an assistance program for 2004 -2006 (which roughly coincides with the period o f political transition). At the end o fthe TSS period, staff will review the situation (both social stability and implementation o f economic reforms) as well as the status o f preparation o f a full PRSP, with a view to moving to a formal Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) as soon as conditions allow.
31. Overall, Bank support duringthe 2001 TSS period has been credited to have made a critical contribution to the political and economic stabilization o f the country -by the highest Governmental authorities, the UNSpecial Representative o f the Secretary General, donors, and civil society. A relationship o f trust has beendeveloped with the Government and key stakeholders (including private sector and civil society), which has beeninstrumentalindefining and implementing the program o f economic reforms currently underway and insupporting the overall recovery effort. 83, DRC's transport network i s organized around the Congo river and its tributaries, which i s complemented by a network o f airport facilities. The pre-war road network was essentially designed to "close" the loop formed by the river (through the Route Nationale 1,RN 1,between Kinshasa and Lubumbashi) and to connect populated areas to the river andthe RN 1. It was relatively poorly developed (58,300 kilometers o fnational and regional roads, and about 86,600 kilometers o f secondary and rural roads, i.e. a total o f 145,000 kilometers), and consisted mainly o f earthroads (less than2 percent o f the network was paved). Its dilapidation duringthe conflict (due to both damage and lack o f maintenance) has resulted inthe isolation o f entire provinces, which have been forced into autarky and where living conditions are appalling.
84. Rehabilitation o f the transport network i s supported under earlier Bank-funded projects, mainly the EERP, EMRRP, and EESRSP. After full completion of the works financed through these projects, the RN 1 shouldbe passable again from Matadi (the country's seaport) to Kinshasato Lubumbashi - andthe links connecting the densely- populated Eastern provinces to the Congo river (RN 4) andto the RN 1(RN2) should also have beenre-opened. The backbone o fthe system having been reconstituted, the next challenge consists inre-connecting isolated regions to this backbone (as spelledout inthe PMPTR).

Inthis context, the following criteria were adopted for the selection o fpriorities: (i) o f priority degree expressed by stakeholders during the provincial-level consultations that took place for the preparation o fthe PMPTR; (ii) expected economic and social impact (which should be significant and could materialize rapidly); (iii) feasibility o f implementation within a relative short period o f time; and (iv) scope o f work.

140. The proposedProject i s a high-risk,high-gain enterprise. Research and experience show that external assistance can play a key role inconsolidating fragile post- conflict situations and facilitating economic recovery. The risks o f engagement have hence to be balanced with the risks o f inaction, which are considerable. The approach suggested here consists inadopting a pro-active risk mitigation strategy rather than a risk avoidance approach -that i s to identify key factors o f risks and design ways to minimize their potential impact.
141. Through consultations with bothother donors and Congolese stakeholders, Bank staff have identified two maintypes o f risks:
0 Country-level risks. These include:
(i)Theriskthatthepoliticaltransitionprocessstalls,withasignificantimpact on security conditions and eventually on political stability. This wouldjeopardize the achievements ofthe Project's objective -althoughit may not annul some of the Project's expectedpositive outcomes (e.g., rehabilitation oflocal infrastructure). This risk has, however, been diminishingover the last four years.
The Bank will carefully monitor political developments inthe DRC and its neighbors, with a view to scaling back, suspending programs, or shifting focus elsewhere ifpolitical instability or renewedconflict threatens the achievement o f objectives.
(ii)Therisksassociatedwiththefragilityof thesecuritysituationinsomeareas. Some Project areas may be affectedby renewed insecurity during implementation. Insuch a context, there i s a risk o f isolated incidents, involving either local populations or armed groups.
The Government and other relevant authorities have agreed to provide guarantees for the safety o f workers and equipment, andto take appropriate measures to that effect. Incase o f security incidents, the Bank or the Governrnent could decideto suspend executionof, or cancel part or the whole of specific contracts (with adequate compensation to the relevant contractors). (iii)Therisksresultingfromthecurrentlackof administrativecapacityin particular at the local level. Despite its impressive track record o f economic reforms over the last two years, the Government still has a relatively weak institutional and administrative capacity, which could lead to delays during implementation. doc.abstracts: The objective of the current Transitional Support Strategy for the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DCR) is to support the recovery and transition process, that is to help consolidate the peace and reconciliation process and to restore the foundations on which effective poverty alleviation efforts can be successfully undertaken. It includes four strategic elements: (i) security and social stability, which includes consolidating social stability in volatile areas, especially in urban centers, and re-establishing the authority of the State throughout the country; (ii) high and shared growth, which requires a particular effort to rehabilitate transport infrastructure (since the collapse of the transport system is the single most stringent constraint to economic recovery in large parts of the country) and urban infrastructure (for urban centers to effectively regain their central role as market places and pools of capacities); (iii) governance and institutional strengthening, in particular at the provincial level; and (iv) social development, in particular to improve living conditions in urban areas, where a third of DRC's population lives and where quick-wins can be most easily achieved.
